abstract: Variations of the helium/argon ratio of gas bubbles in a mineral spring along a fault zone coincide with fluctuations of areal dilation induced by the earth tide. This observation suggests that deep-seated gases characterized by higher heliumlargon ratios are squeezed out by stress preceding an earthquake.

The author presents a brief review of the progress which has been made in understanding CP violation since its discovery. Experiments in Kaon systems and the measurement of parameters associated with long-lived neutral kaon decay are described. Theoretical ideas about CP violation are briefly considered. Forty eight references are given.

Tsukuba Science City is Japan's new municipal complex of research laboratories and educational facilities. About 30 percent of the nation's government research laboratories and more than 40 percent of its government research manpower are concentrated in the community. A brief history of the monumental project is presented and problems confronting the city are discussed.
